verses.text: There was a man from Ramathaim Zophim, from the hill country of Ephraim, and his name was Elkanah the son of Jeroham, son of Elihu, son of Tohu, son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.
verses.comment: Some sources identify Elkanah as a Levite, but he dwelled among the Ephraimites.

verses.text: He had two wives. The name of one was Hannah, and the name of the other, Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah had no children.
verses.comment: Maintains the distinction between the wives and their children.

verses.text: This man went up from his city year by year to worship and to offer sacrifices to Yahweh of hosts at Shiloh, where Hophni and Phinehas, the two sons of Eli, were priests to Yahweh.
verses.comment: ‘Yahweh of hosts’ reflects the original name (YHWH Tsevaot).

verses.text: When the day came for Elkanah to offer his sacrifice, he would give portions to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Clarifies that portions were given to Peninnah and her children.

verses.text: But to Hannah he gave a double portion, because he loved her, though Yahweh had closed her womb.
verses.comment: The ‘double portion’ is literally ‘one portion for two faces’, meaning a special share.

verses.text: Her rival used to provoke her severely to irritate her, because Yahweh had closed her womb.
verses.comment: ‘Rival’ translates the Hebrew word meaning ‘adversary’.

verses.text: So it went on year by year. Whenever Hannah went up to the house of Yahweh, she was provoked; therefore she wept and did not eat.
verses.comment: Maintains the yearly pattern of Hannah’s sorrow.

verses.text: And Elkanah, her husband, said to her, ‘Hannah, why are you crying? Why do you not eat? Why is your heart sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons?’
verses.comment: Renders Elkanah’s question in modern English, staying close to the Hebrew.

verses.text: After they had eaten and drunk in Shiloh, Hannah rose. Now Eli the priest was sitting on the seat beside the doorpost of the temple of Yahweh.
verses.comment: The ‘temple’ here refers to the tabernacle at Shiloh.

verses.text: She was deeply distressed and prayed to Yahweh, and she wept greatly.
verses.comment: Maintains both Hannah’s deep distress and the intensity of her prayer.

verses.text: She made a vow and said, ‘Yahweh of hosts, if you will indeed look on the affliction of your servant and remember me, and not forget your servant but will give your servant a son, then I will give him to Yahweh all the days of his life, and no razor shall touch his head.’
verses.comment: ‘No razor shall touch his head’ reflects the Nazirite vow (see Num. 6:5).

verses.text: As she continued to pray before Yahweh, Eli observed her mouth.
verses.comment: Stays close to the Hebrew wording.

verses.text: Hannah was speaking in her heart; only her lips moved, and her voice was not heard. So Eli thought she was drunk.
verses.comment: Clarifies Hannah’s silent but intense prayer.

verses.text: Eli said to her, ‘How long will you go on being drunk? Put away your wine from you.’
verses.comment: Renders Eli's rebuke in modern terms while staying literal.

verses.text: But Hannah replied, ‘No, my lord, I am a woman oppressed in spirit. I have drunk neither wine nor strong drink, but I have been pouring out my soul before Yahweh.’
verses.comment: ‘Oppressed in spirit’ translates Hebrew ‘hard of spirit.’

verses.text: Do not regard your servant as a worthless woman, for I have been speaking out of my great anxiety and grief until now.’
verses.comment: ‘Worthless woman’ translates the Hebrew ‘daughter of Belial.’

verses.text: Then Eli answered, ‘Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant your request that you have asked of him.’
verses.comment: ‘Go in peace’ is a typical Hebrew blessing.

verses.text: And she said, ‘Let your servant find favor in your eyes.’ Then the woman went her way and ate, and her face was no longer sad.
verses.comment: Phrase captures Hebrew idiom for cheerfulness.

verses.text: They rose early in the morning and worshiped before Yahweh, then returned and came to their house at Ramah. Elkanah knew Hannah his wife, and Yahweh remembered her.
verses.comment: ‘Knew’ here is a Hebrew euphemism for marital intimacy.

verses.text: And in due time Hannah conceived and bore a son, and she called his name Samuel, saying, ‘Because I asked him of Yahweh.’
verses.comment: ‘Samuel’ sounds like ‘asked of God’ in Hebrew.

verses.text: The man Elkanah and all his household went up to offer to Yahweh the yearly sacrifice and to fulfill his vow.
verses.comment: ‘Yearly sacrifice’ refers to annual pilgrimage to Shiloh.

verses.text: But Hannah did not go up, for she said to her husband, ‘As soon as the boy is weaned, I will bring him, so that he may appear before Yahweh and stay there forever.’
verses.comment: ‘Weaned’ typically meant about three years old in ancient Israel.

verses.text: Elkanah her husband said to her, ‘Do what seems good to you. Wait until you have weaned him; only may Yahweh confirm his word.’ So the woman stayed and nursed her son until she had weaned him.
verses.comment: ‘May Yahweh confirm his word’ reflects Elkanah’s faith in Hannah’s vow.

verses.text: When she had weaned him, she took him up with her, along with a three-year-old bull, one ephah of flour, and a skin of wine. She brought him to the house of Yahweh at Shiloh; and the boy was young.
verses.comment: Footnote: Some manuscripts have 'three bulls.'

verses.text: Then they slaughtered the bull and brought the boy to Eli.
verses.comment: Maintains sacrificial order and presentation.

verses.text: And she said, ‘Oh, my lord! As you live, my lord, I am the woman who was standing here beside you, praying to Yahweh.’
verses.comment: ‘As you live’ is a Hebrew idiom for an oath.

verses.text: For this boy I prayed, and Yahweh has given me my request which I asked of him.
verses.comment: Faithfully echoes Hannah’s words.

verses.text: Therefore I have lent him to Yahweh. As long as he lives, he is lent to Yahweh.’ And he worshiped Yahweh there.
verses.comment: ‘Lent’ (or ‘given’) reflects the Hebrew word for ‘to ask/give over.’
